title: 107_hr2005
content: The Act titled "COBRA Coverage Extension and Affordability Act of 2001" extends the basic COBRA continuation period from 18 months to 5 years. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to extend the COBRA continuation period from 18 months to 5 years for qualifying events not described in paragraph (3)(F). The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to extend the COBRA continuation period to 5 years for qualifying events not described in paragraph (3)(F). Amendments to ERISA include changing the date to 60 months after the qualifying event and making adjustments to paragraph (2)(A). The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to extend the COBRA continuation period to 5 years for qualifying events not described in paragraph (3)(F). Amendments to ERISA include changing the date to 60 months after the qualifying event. Amendments to the Public Health Service Act also adjust the required period to 60 months after the qualifying event. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to extend the COBRA continuation period to 5 years for qualifying events not described in paragraph (3)(F). Amendments to ERISA and the Public Health Service Act also adjust the required period to 60 months after the qualifying event. The amendments made by this section shall apply to plan years beginning on or after January 1, 2002, with respect to individuals whose period of extended coverage has not otherwise expired as of the first day of the first such plan year. SEC. 3. Further extension of COBRA continuation coverage for individuals age 55 or older. Section 4980B(f)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to extend coverage for individuals age 55 or older by removing durational limitations when they reach that age. Section 4980B(f)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to extend coverage for individuals age 55 or older without durational limitations. Amendments to ERISA include adjustments to percentages for extended coverage. The amendment extends coverage for individuals aged 55 or older without durational limitations. Amendments to the Public Health Service Act include adjustments to percentages for extended coverage. The amendment extends coverage for individuals aged 55 or older without durational limitations, adjusting percentages for extended coverage. The amendment extends coverage for individuals aged 55 or older without durational limitations, adjusting percentages for extended coverage to 125 percent. Effective January 1, 2002, the amendments apply to plan years starting on or after that date for individuals whose extended coverage period ends on or after the first day of the first plan year. SEC. 4. 50 PERCENT REFUNDABLE TAX CREDIT TOWARDS PREMIUMS FOR COBRA CONTINUATION COVERAGE. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide a 50 percent refundable tax credit for COBRA continuation coverage premiums. SEC. 25B allows a 50 percent tax credit for continuation health coverage premiums paid by individuals. This credit applies to premiums for coverage under a group health plan that meets specific requirements. Sec. 25B allows a 50% tax credit for COBRA continuation coverage premiums, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2001, for premiums from January 2002 onwards.
